categories.name: Breakfast of Champions: Eggs and Bacon

questions.clue: This breakfast combo of eggs and bacon is a mainstay on diner menus throughout North America.
Originating from the same land that gave us maple syrup, Canadian bacon is also known by this name elsewhere.
In a traditional English breakfast, these egg preparations are typically served alongside bacon, sausages, and other items.
This board game invented in the 1960s involves using cards, but its name might make you think of bacon's crispy texture.
In billiards, ‘breaking a rack’ is likened to the sound of sizzling bacon; this type of shot starts the game.
This classic board game, introduced in 1935, has players buy, sell, and trade properties, often causing family arguments.
In 'The Game of Life', players collect little pink and blue pegs representing this.
Stratego players often rely on this piece, which has the power to defeat all pieces except the spy and the marshal.
Settlers seeking wood or brick often say they 'need sheep' in this popular game where commodities help build roads.
This board game, known as the Japanese chess, employs a defensive strategy to protect a piece called 'Kinchou' or 'King General'.

categories.name: Beyond the Eight Ball: The World of Billiards

questions.clue: This cue sport game often shares its name with a popular breakfast combo, especially when paired with bacon.
To start a game of billiards, you need this many balls for a standard game of pool, excluding the cue ball.
In snooker, this ball must be potted to gain 7 points, the highest of any ball on the table.
Named after a famous place in Canada, this variant of billiards features an unusual table shape and is less known than straight pool.
This billiards term also names an insect known for its persistence; it involves banking the cue ball off multiple cushions.

categories.name: Oh Canada! A Journey Through the Great White North

questions.clue: This breakfast item, often featuring eggs and bacon, is known as the Canadian version of the McMuffin.
This province is not only known for its vast wilderness and cultural festivals but also as the birthplace of the classic board game Trivial Pursuit.
While highly uncommon and unwanted, this household pest known for its resilience can occasionally be found in urban Canadian homes.
This type of bacon is cured and often served on pea meal, and is commonly known to Americans as 'Canadian bacon.'
Not just a reputation for maple syrup, this Canadian city hosted the first World Championships of Billiards in 1873.

categories.name: Strange Survivors: The World of Cockroaches

questions.clue: For 200 points: This is the main component of a cockroach's diet, making them surprisingly useful for cleaning up after breakfast.
For 400 points: These insects can hold their breath for up to 40 minutes, a skill that would help them outlast opponents in a game of underwater billiards.
For 600 points: Known to survive without food for a month, they can continue playing board games for longer than most families during a snow-day lockdown.
For 800 points: In the world of cockroaches, this Canadian city holds the record for the most adventurous species, with over 300 kinds spotted.
For 1000 points: Despite their resilience, cockroaches can't survive this kitchen event that occurs at temperatures above 80 degrees Celsius.

final.clue: This strategy board game, believed to originate from an ancient Roman game, shares part of its modern name with a term for a shot in billiards.
